name: HAT-P-18b
description: HAT-P-18b is a Saturn-like exoplanet orbiting a K-type star. It has a low density and an extended atmosphere with detectable water vapor and an escaping helium tail. The planet has a hazy atmosphere that is depleted in methane compared to equilibrium chemistry predictions.

publications.description: Water and an Escaping Helium Tail Detected in the Hazy and Methane-depleted Atmosphere of HAT-P-18b from JWST NIRISS/SOSS

name: HAT-P-42b
description: HAT-P-42b is an inflated hot Jupiter exoplanet orbiting a G-type star. It has a mass similar to Jupiter but a larger radius, indicating it is less dense. The planet orbits very close to its star with a period of about 4.6 days, giving it a high equilibrium temperature of over 1400 K.

publications.description: Discovery paper: HAT-P-42b and HAT-P-43b. Two Inflated Transiting Hot Jupiters from the HATNet Survey

name: KELT-3 Ab
description: Meet KELT-3 Ab, a fascinating hot Jupiter orbiting a bright star just 210 light-years from Earth! This gas giant is about 1.5 times the mass of Jupiter and 1.35 times its radius, making it a truly massive world. KELT-3 Ab zips around its star in just 2.7 days, much closer than Mercury is to our Sun. Its host star, KELT-3 A, is hotter and larger than our Sun, shining brightly in the night sky. This exoplanet was discovered in 2012 using the transit method, adding to our growing list of known worlds beyond our solar system!
surface_conditions: Gaseous, extremely hot due to close proximity to its star

publications.description: Study on obliquities of exoplanet host stars, including KELT-3 Ab
Search for H-alpha absorption around KELT-3 b

name: TOI-6651 b
description: Meet TOI-6651 b, an intriguing sub-Saturn planet orbiting a distant star! This newly discovered world is about half the size of Jupiter but packs quite a punch with its mass. It zips around its star in just over 5 days, much closer than Mercury is to our Sun. Imagine the view from this planet - its star would appear huge in the sky!
surface_conditions: Gaseous with no solid surface, likely with swirling clouds and strong winds

publications.description: Discovery and characterization of a dense sub-Saturn TOI-6651b
The Revised TESS Input Catalog and Candidate Target List

name: 51 Eri b
description: 51 Eri b is a fascinating young gas giant planet orbiting a distant star. Discovered in 2015 using direct imaging, this planet is helping astronomers understand how giant planets form and evolve. With a mass about 4 times that of Jupiter and orbiting its star at a distance of around 11 AU, 51 Eri b gives us a glimpse into what our own Jupiter may have been like in its youth.
surface_conditions: Gaseous planet with swirling clouds in its atmosphere

publications.description: An updated visual orbit of the directly-imaged exoplanet 51 Eridani b and prospects for a dynamical mass measurement with Gaia
Hint of curvature in the orbital motion of the exoplanet 51 Eridani b using 3 years of VLT/SPHERE monitoring
Revisiting the atmosphere of the exoplanet 51 Eridani b with VLT/SPHERE

name: COCONUTS-2 b
description: Meet COCONUTS-2 b, a fascinating cold exoplanet orbiting a young M dwarf star just 10.9 light-years away from Earth! This gas giant is about 6 times more massive than Jupiter and slightly larger in size. It's on an incredibly wide orbit, circling its star at a distance of over 6,000 times that between Earth and the Sun. Despite its chilly temperature of 434 Kelvin (about 161°C or 322°F), COCONUTS-2 b offers exciting opportunities for studying planetary formation and evolution!

publications.description: The Second Discovery from the COol Companions ON Ultrawide orbiTS (COCONUTS) Program: A Cold Wide-Orbit Exoplanet around a Young Field M Dwarf at 10.9 pc

name: GJ 504 b
description: Meet GJ 504 b, a fascinating cold Jupiter-like planet orbiting a Sun-like star! This giant world, discovered in 2013, is about 4 times more massive than Jupiter but slightly smaller in size. Located about 57 light-years away from Earth, GJ 504 b orbits its star at a distance of 43.5 AU, making it one of the coldest and widest-orbit planets ever directly imaged. With a chilly temperature of 544 Kelvin (271°C), this planet gives us a unique glimpse into the outer reaches of alien solar systems!
surface_conditions: Cold gas giant with a methane-rich atmosphere

publications.description: Direct Imaging of a Cold Jovian Exoplanet in Orbit around the Sun-like Star GJ 504
Direct Imaging Detection of Methane in the Atmosphere of GJ 504 b

name: Ross 458 (AB)b
description: Ross 458 (AB)b is a fascinating gas giant planet orbiting a binary star system located about 11.7 light-years from Earth. Discovered in 2010 through direct imaging, this planet is much larger than Jupiter, with a mass of about 11.3 Jupiter masses and a radius slightly larger than Jupiter's. Despite its size, Ross 458 (AB)b has a relatively cool temperature of 677 Kelvin, making it one of the coldest known exoplanets. Its atmosphere contains detectable amounts of methane, hydrogen, water vapor, and potassium. The planet orbits very far from its host stars at a distance of about 1168 AU, which is nearly 30 times farther than Neptune is from our Sun!
surface_conditions: Gaseous with detectable methane, hydrogen, water vapor, and potassium in its atmosphere. Likely has sulfide clouds.

publications.description: Clouds in the Coldest Brown Dwarfs: Fire Spectroscopy of Ross 458C
The properties of the T8.5p dwarf Ross 458C

name: eta Tel b
description: eta Tel b is a fascinating brown dwarf companion orbiting the young A-type star eta Telescopii. Located about 49.5 light-years away in the beta Pictoris moving group, this system is only about 18 million years old. The brown dwarf orbits its host star at a wide separation of about 218 AU, with a nearly edge-on orbit that is almost coplanar with the star's debris disk. Its mass is estimated to be about 48 Jupiter masses, placing it firmly in the brown dwarf regime. This system provides valuable insights into the formation and evolution of substellar companions.
surface_conditions: Gaseous brown dwarf with no solid surface

publications.description: A JWST MIRI MRS View of the η Tel Debris Disk and its Brown Dwarf Companion
Astrometric and photometric characterization of eta Tel B combining two decades of observations

name: GU Psc b
description: Meet GU Psc b, a fascinating planetary-mass companion discovered in 2014! This giant world orbits a young M3 star called GU Psc, located about 48 light-years from Earth. With a mass of about 11 Jupiter masses and a radius 1.35 times that of Jupiter, GU Psc b is a true cosmic heavyweight. What makes this planet truly extraordinary is its enormous distance from its star - it orbits at a whopping 2000 AU, which is about 50 times farther than Pluto is from our Sun! This ultra-wide orbit means GU Psc b has a chilly surface temperature of around 1050 Kelvin. Imagine a world where methane swirls in the atmosphere, creating an alien landscape unlike anything in our solar system. GU Psc b is a captivating example of the diverse worlds that exist in our galaxy, waiting to be explored!

publications.description: Discovery of a Wide Planetary-mass Companion to the Young M3 Star GU Psc

name: PZ Tel b
description: PZ Tel b is a fascinating young brown dwarf companion orbiting the star PZ Tel. Located about 51.5 light-years away in the Beta Pictoris moving group, this celestial body was discovered in 2010 through direct imaging. With an estimated mass of about 27 Jupiter masses, PZ Tel b is much larger than typical planets but smaller than stars, placing it in the intriguing category of brown dwarfs. Its orbit is highly eccentric, taking it as close as 23 AU and as far as 41 AU from its host star. The system's young age of about 23 million years provides a unique opportunity to study the early stages of brown dwarf evolution.
surface_conditions: Gaseous, with a hot atmosphere of about 2987 K

publications.description: Dynamical Mass of the Young Brown Dwarf Companion PZ Tel B
Detection of Halpha emission from PZ Telescopii B using SPHERE/ZIMPOL

name: Wolf 940 b
description: Meet Wolf 940 b, a fascinating brown dwarf companion orbiting a distant star! This celestial body is about 26 times more massive than Jupiter, making it a true giant in our cosmic neighborhood. Located an incredible 400 AU from its host star (that's 400 times the distance between Earth and our Sun!), Wolf 940 b takes us on a journey to the outer reaches of its solar system. Despite its enormous size, it's only slightly smaller than Jupiter in radius, hinting at its dense, compact nature. Discovered in 2009 through the exciting method of direct imaging, Wolf 940 b continues to captivate astronomers with its unique characteristics and the mysteries it holds about brown dwarf formation and evolution.
surface_conditions: Gaseous, with a dense atmosphere typical of brown dwarfs

publications.description: The discovery of an M4+T8.5 binary system

name: kappa And b
description: Meet kappa And b, a fascinating 'super-Jupiter' orbiting a young B-type star about 50 parsecs from Earth. This massive gas giant, with a mass about 13 times that of Jupiter, was discovered in 2013 through direct imaging. It orbits its host star at an impressive distance of about 100 astronomical units, taking over 500 years to complete one orbit. With a scorching temperature of around 1850 Kelvin, this young planet (only about 47 million years old) provides valuable insights into planetary formation and evolution.
surface_conditions: Gaseous, extremely hot atmosphere with swirling clouds

publications.description: Study on host star metallicity of directly imaged wide-orbit planets
Atmospheric characterization and orbital modeling of kappa Andromeda b
